text:
There are so many marketing roles (content, dev rel) for people who have technical experience and knowledge, so you may have an easier time with the transition than you think. People would be willing to take a chance on your minimal marketing and writing experience since you know a technical subject so well and can speak authentically/authoritatively to that audience.

I don’t think anything you learn in higher ed will help you a ton in a content marketing role. (Unless you honed your writing skills more, especially copywriting, potentially). Instead I’d look for courses, mentorship, exp., freelancing ops, etc. by people who do content marketing in the field you want (assuming tech).

elements.text:

Instead I’d look for courses, mentorship, exp., freelancing ops, etc. by people who do content marketing in the field you want (assuming tech).

text:
In many parts of the world, that's not necessary. What I suggest to get you an answer that's most relevant to you: Figure out what jobs in particular you're working toward. Like if you're aiming to work for a major employer in your country, then find out what people in those jobs have education wise. Try to ask some of them directly, especially hiring managers.

Why I suggest that: Various countries and companies can have different expectations, especially with management roles. For instance, in the U.S., some Fortune 100 or 500 companies will value credentials more than say startups. And judging by your time zone, I think you're in India, where credentials tend to be valued more.

You mentioned wanting to be a manager. That could even mean shooting for an exec role / chief content officer, which is a position that more companies are creating / elevating.

Personally, I'm in the U.S. and it doesn't usually take another degree to work successfully in content. For me, because I joined an exec team, I had to learn a bunch of business and strategic thinking. But rather than get another degree, I studied on my own, learned on the job and volunteer-coached for two years at a tech incubator (they accepted me based on a recommendation from someone they trusted). Because they brought in successive cohorts of startups from around the world, I was able to see many businesses and business models from the inside and help them come up with strategies and solve problems. For me, that gave me business chops that I couldn't have gotten otherwise, especially because content is my second career. (I used to work in news.) And because I learned all that, that helped me break into seven-figure compensation packages between cash and equity. (Besides learning business and strategy, and serving at the exec level at a startup that eventually went public, I also started advising other companies for cash and equity.)

Right now, some of us in content are outliers when it comes to opportunities to lead major initiatives, become instrumental in growing companies as execs, build large teams and earn accordingly. But content has reached a tipping point — with more and more companies realizing that they're must-have jobs to acquire users and compete, because traditional marketing’s effectiveness has waned over years. That means there will be increasing opportunities for content leaders who think like business people. Like right now, if I could clone a dozen of me, I could hire them all out within a few weeks to good companies.

And if you want to maybe build your own company one day, it might help to learn business and strategic thinking.

text: Hi everyone! So I've been applying for senior content marketing manager or head/director of content roles at tech companies, and I'm not having a ton of luck getting past the initial screening. I'm a content marketer with more than 12 years of experience (between journalism and diff content roles), including experience leading a small team of content writers, building a content strategy from scratch, and developing content initiatives that drive measurable results. I don't quite understand why I'm not getting many interviews when I know I'm qualified for the roles I'm after. My goal is to join a small/mid-size company that markets to creatives/creators, but I've also been applying to roles outside of that. Does anyone have any tips or feedback?

elements.text: Hi everyone! I don't quite understand why I'm not getting many interviews when I know I'm qualified for the roles I'm after. My goal is to join a small/mid-size company that markets to creatives/creators, but I've also been applying to roles outside of that. Does anyone have any tips or feedback?

text: Here's my resume if anyone is open to taking a look and offering feedback!

text: I know one of the things I was told when I had the same issue was to simplify my resume, eliminate the graphic elements and focus on results I delivered in each of my roles. The "bots" apparently are confused by non-traditional resume layouts.

elements.text: I know one of the things I was told when I had the same issue was to simplify my resume, eliminate the graphic elements and focus on results I delivered in each of my roles. The "bots" apparently are confused by non-traditional resume layouts.

text: Hi Julissa! I'm not a hiring manager for those kind of roles so take with a grain of salt, but I took a look at your resume and one of the things that jumped out at me was it could help to include more specifics in terms of the metrics you influenced. I.e. how many customer success stories did you create per month/quarter/total etc? did you use NPS to determine "advocates"? average NPS score/percent improvement etc would be good to include. I would look bullet by bullet and think of ways you can express what you did more concretely.

I would look bullet by bullet and think of ways you can express what you did more concretely.

text:
Nothing that’s a super big red flag (and I do hire for these types of roles), but a couple things I noticed:
• If you’re aiming for Senior Manager/Director roles, you may want to position yourself more as a content marketing leader vs practitioner in your headline, about me paragraph, and experience bullets. It’s a subtle change, and you’re already doing it in some places, but could impact how you’re perceived.
• The first role on your resume is Customer Marketing Manager and someone has to scroll to the bottom of page 1 to get to content marketing experience (although I do recognize that your current role has elements of a content role). Your headline on LinkedIn also starts with “Customer Marketer”. This might cause an ATS or hiring manager to skip over you because it may create the perception that you’re changing fields. One way I’ve seen this addressed is to list all your roles on Page 1 and then get into the details on subsequent pages. This also allows you to pare your resume down to 1 page when needed.
Finally, my one question for you is: do you always submit a cover letter? If not, I highly highly recommend it for content roles, especially senior ones. I personally prioritize qualified applicants with strong cover letters over those who didn’t submit one. It’s a piece of content marketing that proves you can walk the walk.

text:
Yes can absolutely list your roles on 1 page without details. If your challenge is getting past the initial screen to the interview process, it might be a good idea. I’m not sure I can share examples I’ve seen without violating people’s privacy, but the way I’ve seen it done is listing all the roles on page 1 and then the details on subsequent pages. That way if someone only reads page 1, they’re still getting the important info.

Your resume says you’ve led teams…wouldn’t that make you a leader? Leader is a very subjective term.

text:
Hey- I am in this position / interview often for Director level roles.

I second some of the feedback that the only thing that jumps out to me about this would be the titles. The first one is customer marketing, and if I were skimming the resume (which sadly lots of recruiters do) I don't think there is enough "Content Manager" roles jumping out at me. Is there anything you can do with the titles to make them a bit more senior?

Second making this more results and data focused. Do you have an online portfolio/website? As someone who recently interviewed for these types of roles, everyone needed to see an online portfolio that was project based vs writing sample based.

If you'd like I can share my resume and online portfolio (it's a work in progress for sure but could be good to peak at someone else in the same hiring spot).

text:
No if it's listed that should be great! Title wise, outside of just adjusting it better reflect what you do *(I'm sure people feel strongly about this tactic) I would update your LinkedIn header to call out that you're a senior content marketer and open each job with a small description of what you've achieved/done that is very impactful and highlights your seniority.

So here is one of my jobs on my resume for example:

text:
I highlight my wins, and impact to the company and two of the biggest projects I managed\executed (with results).

Someone else gave great advice that focusing on results highlights leaders, focusing on day to day/production level items tends to lean a bit more junior (i.e.: manage a blog, create engaging content, help with emails, etc.)

I spoke with some friends who are more senior than me, and who hire director level and they were fantastic with hard (but smart) feedback for me.

text: And don’t underestimate the value of having a connection at the company. Use LinkedIn to look up any first- or second-degree connections you have, find out how to get in front of someone there, and ask them if they’d be willing to either refer you to the hiring manager (if you know them well) or if they’re willing to share any insights about the role or the team (if you don’t). Sometimes just getting that intro or name recognition makes all the difference.

text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: junior (1-3 years of experience)

"What, if any, are the differences between a Content Manager and a Content Marketing Manager? Do they both lead the same career path? Which one is more senior? When applying to one, is the other title sufficient? And vice versa? Which role would you recommend for someone who is interested in more senior managerial and director roles in marketing?
"

Use a tool like Jobscan, which basically helps you keyword-optimize your resume against the job ad you're applying for. As someone else noted, you need to adjust the formatting of your resume so the ATS (applicant tracking system) can parse it well. Google to find explainer videos on that topic. Very eye-opening! Also, don't be afraid to reach out to people at these companies, especially potential hiring managers, if you think you're a great fit. The ATS filters make it exceedingly difficult to get your resume seen by a real person.

The ATS filters make it exceedingly difficult to get your resume seen by a real person.

text:
I imagine for a lot of orgs, there is no difference between the two titles, either in role & responsibilities or pathing.

However, if there _is_ a difference anywhere, I'd say Content Manager is more focused on a pure content production team (as a service for an org, measured in output), rather than a Content Marketer, where the focus is leveraging content to drive conversion/leads/revenue.

Where that differentiation in meaning does exist, I would say the better title is the CMM as it could easily grow to leading an important performance channel in a Director role, or pivot into Product Marketing, Performance Marketing, etc.

Rather than relying on title alone, I'd look at JDs and talk to recruiters to understand how their org thinks about these roles/titles. Often, people have very arbitrary reasons for assigning one title or another and it's something you can influence during the recruiting process too.

Rather than relying on title alone, I'd look at JDs and talk to recruiters to understand how their org thinks about these roles/titles. Often, people have very arbitrary reasons for assigning one title or another and it's something you can influence during the recruiting process too.
